content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game is alot of fun, its not graphics heavy. It is welll done. The storyline and plot are well thought out and interesting. The quests are nonlinear, you can go explore and choose what and where you wish to go. You get to choose which quests you want to do or not do. There are multiple endings. The game system is easy to learn and logical. I have found no glitches, lag or crashes. It has great replayablity.  There are assorted classes and skills and new classes open up as you play. There is an achievement list. Different levels of difficulty and hardcore death or not as you desire. There is minimal loading on world map and only a bit between areas in dungeons. It is a good solid game and well worth the money.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												I have 100+ hours on this game already - and that's on Steam only;  you can get a free non-Steam version of ToME on its website - so I feel it's time to make a review.First things first, it's a roguelike alright: permadeath, randomized world, tile-based graphics, yadda yadda. And yet it's a great introduction to the roguelike genre, because there are options to play it with a number of lives, or even unlimited ones, to get the hang of the game! Not EVERYTHING is randomized (there are fixed artifacts, fixed locations, etc but it still feels like a roguelike). Also, it contains intuitive UI and gameplay. For example, there are practically no consumables like potions and scrolls - not in the sense we're accostumed to. Instead, your powers (and some items) have cooldowns along with, naturally, some resource management (stamina, mana, psi, etc.). Cast X spell/move? Wait Z turns to use it again. Or, maybe, use some talent that can reset some cooldowns ;-). That cooldown system is really intuitive and just one of the many reasons I'm in love with ToME.Now let's talk about the world. I'm not an old ToME follower but unless I'm mistaken, it used to be set in Tolkien's Middle-Earth, until it was changed to a more original lore. And it's a great lore: the continent of Eyal was, some time ago, devastated by catatrophic used of magic (i.e the Spellblaze), there are still mage hunters (Zigur), there are political issues (Halflings are militaristic and even used to slave Yeeks); heck, even the demons have a touching and fantastic backstory! So, in terms of lore, the game has good stuff to offer. Some of the actual places are very creative, too: tunnels of sand that can collapse and swallow the uncautious adventurer, underwater ruins, necromancer dens, forests, deserts, and so on...In terms of races/classes, there are 11 races and 26 classes, allowing for tons of builds. There are your classic warriors (Bulwark, Berserker), mages (Archmage, Necromancer) and even exotic classes that can manipulate things like their foes' dreams (Solipsist), draconic powers (Wyrmic) and even time itself (Temporal Warden, Paradox Mage)! Most of the races and classes are unlocked as you progress in the game and do certain tasks, which aren't too hard, honestly. But if you're impatient, then you can look for an addon (mod) that unlocks everything right out of the bat. ;-)Anyway, it's getting too long. I typed all of that to convice you to PLAY THE GAME. Seriously, play it. It's great, no matter if you're a roguelike veteran or new to the genre (like me, actually)!

												The graphics are awful. UI is a pain. But somehow this game has become the one I've spent more time playing than any other on Steam. Tales of Maj'Eyal is one of the best roguelikes ever made with its creative classes, worlds to discover, and surprises to keep players entertained. Also, it does away with tedium like hauling junk to sell at shops and hoarding potions that never get used. It's a solo game, but with connected chat one never really feels alone in the world. Sometimes the game designer appears and bestows stuff upon the connected players. Plus if you like achievements, then this is the game to play.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												(I have just under a hundred hours logged into this game from before it got onto steam.)It is an interesting roguelike that plays a little differently from others of its' genre.. If you want an idea of what makes it different;No identification. All items are identified immediately upon picking them up. This wasn't the case in earlier versions of the game, but the large and increasing number of fixed artifacts and no need for identification scrolls made it somewhat pointless.Potions and scrolls are replaced by infusions and runes, which give on-demand abilities that consume no permanent resources -with a limited number of slots for these abilities. Regeneration infusions are the primary method of healing, replacing healing potions, and runes of teleportation replace scrolls of teleportation as an escape from trouble. Nothing is lost in their use, but they have cooldowns.A system for "extra lives". Before you crucify the game, extra lives is either a startup option akin to lowering the difficulty("roguelike" mode for one life, "Adventure" for three, "Exploration" for unlimited) or through very rare artifacts or abilities in-game. Also, it doesn't save you if you decided to hug an Elven Corruptor and he blows you up the first turn you revive.Disable-heavy combat. Simply, being resilient to damage through armor or magical resistance is not as important as being difficult to disable. Stuns and confusion are the leading killers, not high burst damage. This makes it very easy to get chain-disabled and killed if you haven't prepared properly with high saving throws or effect clears(certain runes and infusions will remove a detrimental effect from you on use). All of these things combined could make it seem like a somewhat casual roguelike, but in practice it isn't really any easier than similar contemporary roguelikes. The only element that is truly missing is resource management. You still must assess risks, prepare for and pick your battles carefully, and adapt to what the RNG has provided you. The cooldowns-based combat and lack of resource management should be considered an interesting spin, not an intentional dumbing down.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												ToME is a thoroughly enjoyable old-school fantasy RPG with loads of races, classes, skills, items, and enemies, deep and interesting quests in a large world, and a variety of difficulty and permadeath options, all wrapped up in a graphical package with a decent UI.Great things:- Story: lore abounds throughout the world- Breadth and depth of world: dozens of dungeons, some quite deep, on multiple continents, as well as towns, roaming NPCs, and plenty of areas that are unlocked by quests- Variety of monsters: there are rats and orcs, but so much more, as well - necromancers, fantastic magical creatures, hordes of wyrms... the list goes on- Variety of gear: multiple tiers with many levels of quality, tons of interesting egos, artifacts, and unusual things like lanterns and charms- Variety of maps and dungeons: every place feels different and has a different theme and story- Variety of graphical sprites: some dungeons look alike, but most places have a distinct look - also, plenty of weapon, armor, and character sprites to keep things interesting- High ratio of progression to tedium- Exploration mode gives you infinite lives, for those who like an easy game once in a while- 1,600+ achievements- Many UI and graphics configuration and customization options- Extremely good price for the amount of depth and replayability (less than one US cent per achievement, too)Not-so-great things:- Can feel very unbalanced at times (compared to other modern roguelikes): it's common to step into an enemy's line-of-sight and die instantly from a sudden powerful attack, even on normal difficulty- Default tiles are a bit painful on the eyes: I prefer the OldRPG tiles from the Steam Workship, which give the game a somewhat more Legend of Zelda-like look- In-game map is just colored blocks with no additional information- Automatic waypoint navigation is only available through add-ons, and the choices there are imperfect at best- High-DPI displays: if you zoom the UI, the hotbar is buggy unless the hotbar icon size is set to default (32 pixels)- Linux + NVIDIA: Some graphical flickering and slowness, especially with shader effects enabled

												This is one of the best and most user-friendly "plot" roguelikes.It has everything a typical hardcore roguelike should have, except 150+ keymappings for all the actions.It has nice, fancy graphics and special effects.It has lots of unlocks and achievements you will be struggling hard to get.It has TONS of different player classes, each offering unique experience to the gamer.Finally, it's initially free of charge (check te4.org), and for buying it you get some nice cosmetic stuff, local stash, ability to write in global chat and a badass dwarf hybrid melee + caster class dual-wielding shields.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Tales of Maj'Eyal (TOME for short) is a in turn based roguelike that at first glance is something many would pass over but it comes with an amazing amount of character customization, story and enjoyable difficulty. This game also has, at the time of this review, the most achievements of any game on Steam. There is also an explorer mode which allows you to enjoy the story, up to Insanity mode to maximize the pain. The Steam edition also has a connected community chat in game which allows you to share death messages or interesting finds to talk about. The community is wonderful, the developers also update the game with new features. If you are still unsure about the game you can download the game for free at the developers website. If you like it, consider picking this up on Steam and supporting the developers!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												This is what roguelikes are meant to be. Fair but brutal. Easy to pick up, but can also plot, plan, conive, and strategize to the end of days. Loads of start options (classes, races, that sort) to unlock, with a decent assortment of default-unlocked characters ranging through easy-hard and beginner-complex spectrums. Graphics, sound, music all functional enough to work nicely, backed by gameplay that would've still dwarfed them anyhow if it would've had a big studio throwing insane money at artists to pretty it up. Completely turn-based, so you can jump up to answer the phone or door or grab a snack or whatever else (like just trying to think your way out of a rough patch when it looks like next move could be the last) without needing to find a pause, but you'll likely find yourself already up later than intended claiming to yourself that you'll go to bed after just one more level. Replayability already high when played on regular difficulty and some extra lives allowed, then you can always turn up difficulty while playing one-life mode and playing a class you're less comfortable with to make it more interesting, while also hunting down large amounts of achievements, some of which are challenging all on their own, others are challenging except in the rare case that the RNG components smile on you. Or start a character with difficulty turned down and/or lives set to infinite just to get a better idea of what will and won't work out later before doing it on a "real" savefile. And then you could always get into using or making mods if you're into that. Have spotty internet sometimes? As long as you had it already downloaded, completely works in offline mode (with minor limitations of not getting special event dungeons unlocked if the dev sprinkles it to everybody, and offline mode has a separate shared stash from online mode).Still not sure? Poke around their website, there should still be a free version available (had some minor limitations when I did so years ago, looks like less limits now?). Worth every penny to buy though. Looking forward to getting Embers expansion and checking out its content before or after when I eventually get through more of what's already offered by the base game and Ashes expansion.

												ToME is a fantastic game with a great community. The game really draws you in and you get addicted fast. It's very difficult at times and has some really intense moments as well. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												A pretty brutal roguelike with a very simple easy to use interface. All of the usual fantasy tropes present and accounted for as well as some other fun additions not commonly found in such games. Classes run the gamut from standard beat stick warriors and glass cannon archmages all the way to the strange paradox magi and psionic solipsists.The game can be especially frustrating when playing low hp characters who can die in a single turn if you don't scout ahead so I wouldn't recommend it to anyone with a short temper, but if you're a fan of roguelikes it's a pretty solid addition to your library.And if you're aren't sure you want to buy it you can play the game for free on the creator's website. You can't lose.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												For those of us who can play a game without needing to be wowed by fancy graphics -- but instead be enamoured by the depth, challenge and gameplay of a rogue-like, this is for you. I LOVE this game. So many different race and class combinations and then you realize there are heaven knows how many builds for the character combos you like the most. Fun loot, detailed story (that you can just as well skip if you just want to hack and slash), and every time you play you can unlock a new game mode or race or class to make things more interesting. This brings me back to my C64 days -- where your game HAD to be good by virtue of substance because it was not technically possible to deliver elegant style. You can play for ten minutes or hours on end -- it's a great palette cleanser for other games as well!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												A true roguelike that got rid of some of the arguably unnecessary and frustrating features of roguelikes (e.g. cursed armor that just randomly kills you) and minimizes off-time with it's auto-explore feature.The thing that really shines about this game is the character progression and creation though. Unlike traditional roguelike different classes play COMPLETELY different and indroduce new and interesting mechanics (like the manipulation of time for example). Almost every style of play is to be found here; from being a nasty necromancer and summoning skeletons and bone giants to slaughter your enemies to the time manipulating bow - dual weapon hybrid to the anti-magic "slime mage" that posisons his enemies, summons slimes to control the battlefield and uses PSIBLADES (F***ING PSIONIC LASERSWORDS).In addition to the HUGE amount of classes, the classes themselves are extremly complex by having many different skill-trees to develop and unlock. While some people might see this as a negative I feel like this adds a lot of complexity of depth to the game and makes you able to play classes in completely different ways.TL;DR: DO YOU LIKE DEEP RPGs? DO YOU HATE DYING TO BS AND WANT TO BE RESPONSIBLE FOR YOUR DEATHS? DO YOU NOT MIND F***ING UP AT THE BEGINNING BECAUSE YOU SUCK AT THE GAME?THEN GET THIS FREAKING GAME BECAUSE IT'S EVERYTHING YOU'VE EVER WANTED AN MORE

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												A great Roguelike that makes it easy to get into the genreJust like Dungeons of Dreadmore of SWOTS: The Pit, this game eases you into the idea of a Roguelike gently so that you can try it out without it being quite as brutal as, say, Nethack or DoomRL. The graphics are not a selling point in this title, but the gameplay should be. With tons of unlocks, lots of ways to stat and build characters, castes and quests to choose that will vary gameplay widely, and a big variety of enemies, if you've never gotten into a RL before but would like to try, get this.If you're like me and more experienced in the genre, I still recommend it as this does some interesting things with the forumula--the capacity for kind of rogue-like not-quite-permadeath; the ability to (for example) forswear all arcane magic in exchange for joining a new faction of the game and learning magic-disrupting powers; the fact that one school of magic is powered mostly by paradox (and you can meet and kill yourself! ?.?) means that this is much more in-depth a game than the RLs of the 90s. Sure, you can pick this up free on the developer's website, but you should pay for it (here or there) just to support the effort. 8.5 out of 10--which back in the old days on PC Gamer, meant that this is a classic well worth your time. :)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I told myself not to write a review before I've actually beaten the game, and while it took me longer than expected (admittedly not in small part due to me fooling around instead of playing serious builds), this is it.This is hands-down my favorite game ever.Before i begin: You can play the game for free by downloading it from te4.org (the official website).Purchasing the Steam version will get you a few perks you would otherwise get by donating. (those aren't major, however the DLC is and is in my opinion definitely worth it)So do test it first before buying and then buy it if you want to support the creator (mostly a single guy by the way).Things that are great:-It's in many parts a traditional roguelike (which I am a fan of), that means: turn-based combat, procedurally generated dungeons.-It's in some parts more forgiving than traditional roguelikes: option to choose between permadeath, a limited number of lives or unlimited lives (while the last takes away from the fun imo), multiple difficulty settings (easier, which will not get you any achievements, normal, which is pretty hard, on to various degrees of insanity)-the most interesting choice of classes i know from virtually anywhere: There are the classic Berserker, Archer, Archmage but also things like Mindslayer, Oozemancer, Brawler, Solipsist.-Every class is played differently: due to completely different sets of skills and build possibilities, each class has its own unique playstyle.-no grinding: all dungeons can only be cleared once, there are no respawning mobs. Additionally there are no consumables, these are replaced by "inscriptions" which are infinitely usable, but on a cooldown, meaning there is nothing you have to save up for a big bossfight, but you still have to think about when you use what in that fight.-impressive gameworld: The sheer amount of lore there is for you to find is impressive. This is a point where it differs from many classic roguelikes: It has a main quest, a story, and lots of backstory, all of which I personally found to be interesting and engaging. The various dungeons feel interesting and different.-it's challenging: You actually have to either think about what you are doing, or prepare to die a lot. You might die a lot even if you do until you figure some things out. To me that is a good thing, to others it might not be i guess, but that's what exploration mode (unlimited lives) is for: figuring stuff out.-great community: Why is this important? While it is not a multiplayer game, there is an in game online chat. It shows character deaths and character achievements (this can be turned on/off) and can be used for chatting. This is extremely helpful for asking about things you might need to know, and in my experience the community will be more than happy to help.The things you might not like:-Graphics: This is a Tileset-based game. It doesnt feature great animations or anything like that apart from spell effects. If that is extremely off-putting to you, i'm sorry. As to the tileset itself, I like it, others might not.-It may not be easy to get into: There are many stats to keep track of, sometimes making it hard to decide which items to take over others, the GUI is great in my opinion, but at the start it can take a bit to get used to it. So if you have any questions while playing: dont hesitate to ask in chat!-it's challenging: see above-If you are an achievement completionist, you might get into problems with this game. Just a warning.All  in all, i very much recommend to try it.And dont give up after a few deaths :P

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I was very skeptical about whether this game would be any good.  At this point I can say it is more than good.  This roguelike is pretty brilliant if you ask me.  And I think it's developed by just one dude.  That's the impression I've been given.Turn-based combat, a large amount of enemy variety, some randomly generated elements, and strong character building makes for a good amount of fun and diversity in every playthrough.  There are many races and classes for you to choose from too, all with their own unique qualities in the form of different stats and skills.  There's good variety in the armor, weapons, and the many other items you can find and equip as well.  Pretty good sized map to explore, and the game has well written lore and dialogue.  Lots of humor, but also some pretty twisted stuff.  It's great.You can also select a difficulty setting AND a permadeath setting at character creation.  The two are separate things.  There are 5 difficulty settings ranging from Easier to Madness.  And 3 permadeath settings.  Roguelike which gives you one life (unless you find a rare way to resurrect yourself).  Adventure which gives you multiple lives.  And Exploration which gives you infinite lives.  I've mostly been trying Nightmare/Roguelike.There are 1386 achievements.  Most of them are repeated achievements for different difficulties/permadeath settings, but if you do an achievement on a high difficulty/permadeath setting you can get the lower ones along with it (consult the Steam forums to find out how).  Along with achievements, there are a bunch of secrets you can unlock.The game also has two DLC.  Both are cheap, so if you buy the game pick them up as well.  One adds new classes and two new zones.  The other is a Steam UI celebrating their launch on steam.  I believe there may be more DLC on the way but I can't say anything for certain.Worth every penny.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												The most complete turn-based rpg you will find in steam, and it's not only good because of the enormous contents it has to offer, but also the great amount of replayability that makes this game really catchy.Prior to playing this, i weren't really into said kind of games, thinking those're boring. This game were my first try, and today is a game i often play when i'm bored.Pretty simple at the beginning, you choose a class, a race, a name and a gender, then the gamemod (you'll unlock them as you play) and the difficulty/lifes for your character, with complete freedom to choose between some easy and relaxing way to start understanding how the game works, or to begin with an insane journey with only one life that you'll probably lose very soon.As i mentioned, you can unlock other gamemods while you play and complete certain tasks, and same thing is for other classes and races to have further plays with, trying out new playstyles and techniques.It can be an unfair experience most of the times, even when playing with a standard difficulty and with a set amount of lives, so don't try to get too upset when losing your character from a single killing blow by a "something"-caster (if not "anything"-caster), or for losing a fight with strange unique monsters that have for some reason your same skills/spells, or by overpowered monsters that have 40 more levels than you, that appeared when moved a little harmless rock.It's surely an experience that should be tried by those who even thinks to dislike this genre of games, because this is a new perspective that should be taken into account if you didn't liked a previous one of the same subject; this doesn't mean that this game will be valued the same way by everyone who tries it, since it still is (and always be) one of the most difficult games, where to succeed one of the best way is not to win it, but to lose trying to do it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												This is the best roguelike on steam. Strikes a perfect balance between usability/user friendliness with depth and complexity. I'll review this game by highlighting what I think sets it apart from other games in the genre.No consumable items - TOME doesn't have potions, scrolls, or wands. You choose a limited number of abilities that give you the function that consumables play in other games - quick heal, regen, teleport, blink, fireball, etc. This eliminates the issues lots of people have with hoarding consumables, not knowing when to use them, the pain of having them destroyed, etc. Picking and choosing the right abilities adds a layer of depth that doesn't exist in other roguelikes. Fast - this game plays lightning fast and is very streamlined, thanks to the lack of consumables. Of course, it's turn based, so it's only as fast as you want...but I tend to play pretty fast, and lots of roguelikes feel sluggish in comparison.Broad - Lots of classes, from your standard mage and warrior to the cool weird things like Chronomancers and Wyrmics (dragon-fighters). Deep - The different classes feel distinct. In addition to the obvious (different skills and equipment), different types of classes have different types of resources (mana/stamina/equilibrium/hate/probably some other ones) that work in different ways.  Combat Is Fun  - This is the only roguelike I've played where melee combat is actually fun. You get lots of buttons to push that do different things. In most roguelikes, the coolest thing about your melee character is the equipment you find. In TOME, you can actually do cool♥♥♥♥♥♥- charge, shout, whirlwinds, cleaves, etc. Simple - This doesn't mean easy and it doesn't mean shallow - it just means simple. Clean, streamlined design. The action bar is great - every option your character has is on it, so you always know what you can and can't do. No navigating labyrinthine menus, no checking your inventory after you died and remembering you could have used your blink, etc.Overworld - Like ADOM and not like Crawl, TOME features a static overworld that's always the same and features the same dungeons/locations, which are themselves randomized. This isn't necessarily better or worse, just putting it out there.This game is an absolute blast. If you liked Dungeons of Dreadmor, you owe it to yourself to take a step up to a more serious and more interesting game. :)

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Graphics are simple but the mechanics are deep. Classes have skills like in WoW but with more skills and more customization akin to an ARPG. Things that could be tedious are streamlined not to be, for example loot you don't want is automatically disenchanted for gold at end of level. The campaign to actually win is long, but not too long. You can play with only 1 life or with a few lives and unlock a few more the further you get, which is great because even a very experienced player will likely die a few times on nightmare difficulty and above. The classes are completely unique and have a lot going on with them. If you enjoy min/maxing a brand new class with a bunch of abilities, you can do that for hundreds of hours since there are so many classes. This game has a tendency to make time pass by faster than expected like in Civilization games. Only negative I have with it is that the early game on the highest difficulties is too unforgiving.Also my initial impression of the game wasn't great, it took me about an hour to start to realize how good it was.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												This is seriously one of the best rogue-likes out there!  It is quite punishing, but not oppressively so like Dungeon Crawl.  There is a steep learning curve, your first adventure, or first few dozen adventures will probably not yield you anything game-wise, but you will learn.  Playing around a little bit, you will start seeing synergies with how the different skills for the classes interact with each other, and then start building yourself a truly powerful character.For me, nothing feels better than having your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you by the game repeatedly, and then, figuring out the class you're trying to do, and waltzing through the end-game content like a seasoned veteran...because you are!  You will learn the strategies, understand the tactics, shape your reactions to the situations appropriately, and you will conquer!  You will earn your end-game god-like status not by farming, or investing time at the expense of brainpower, you will earn it through sweat and, sometimes, tears of frustration, but you absolutely will earn it, and when you deal that final blow, you will feel like you truly accomplished something great......and then you will start the process over again, learning a new class!

Posted: March 27
												Five levels of difficulty, ranging from "Oh, a challenging RPG" to "I just spent 3 hours getting killed in the starting area". ToME is a turn-based isometric roguelike with a global chat, so you can comiserate with fellow adventurers around the globe. +Deep combat mechanics aided by hundreds of spells and abilities+Super challenging, requires very strategic play+Dozens of unlocks including races, classes, skill trees and cosmetic items+Great replayability, almost required considered the amount of deaths you'll have+Constant updates/New content. The developer will randomly log on and grant everyone currently playing special abilities or easter eggs.-Laughably bad graphics.-Glitchy at times-Extremely steep learning curve-The game is so complex it's practically byzantine (it's a word, look it up). Guides are almost required.Have you seen the amount of achievements? Get this game.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												Tales OF Maj'Eyal is an incredibly complex and deep Rogue-like game with turn-based combat and a large amount of content.I've put more then 100 hours into the game and I haven't unlocked even half the classes/races (Maybe I just suck). There is a race and class for any type of player, but with this game you will want to try every one of them. Usually I find some quirks to these type of games, but everything you need is there, with a simple interface and all the information you need, so your never left in the dark on what a skill does or why you just died.There is a huge amount of content, with randomly generated dungeons for you to go through and many different quests to partake with many easter eggs to be found. I always seem to find something new and exciting every playthrough. There is also many different gamemodes and difficulties to contour to any player.I think this game is perfect for anyone who loves this genre of game, or even people new to the genre. Graphically its not too complex like ASCII graphics, and once you truly get into the game you will find it hard to stop.The game also has over 1000 achievements for those who like to collect, and with a current price tag of 7$, theres no reason I can think of to stop you from buying this game.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												Honestly, some of the most fun I've had with a roguelike, can only name a few that I'd rank higher than it. Unlike most roguelikes, there's an overworld with towns, said overworld and said towns are not randomly generated, but have fixed layouts, only the dangerous areas that would loosely define as "dungeons" are random in layout. Each option feels quite different, and usually has a somewhat unique play style, with race choice as well as class. The game doesn't exactly feel unfair until mid to late levels when the adventure starts getting into ridiculous territory.Visuals for something as lightweight as this and static sprites are quite nice, there's some 3D effects and 2D effects based on special abilities being used, the sprites are large and detailed enough to know what you're facing before you mouse over it.Controls are fairly simple, opting for an action bar where you can slot all your different items/abilities, which may deter some of the hardcore players of roguelikes. There's also mouse support, and right clicking on your character or other things allows one to play mostly with the mouse if one prefers.Sound is present, there's music for every area, sounds for different attacks and special abilities, nothing to really write home about, but it's not bad.Game mechanics are fairly solid and scale up to the point of more or less halfling going toe to toe with kaiju god-slaying robot of death, though quite a few of the mechanics are not 100% intuitive, difficulty is pretty variable with lots of options. Achievements are a colossal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥though, as a result, as getting an achievement in one difficulty setting doesn't unlock it for any others, and a lot of the achievements have 12 variations or so based on difficulty settings. Will say that some randomly generated enemies can be impossible to kill, I had an issue with a named bone giant who was impossible to kill at the level cap with ridiculously strong abilities as a summoner.The game also has a plot and rewards you for being a nice person or a total jerk as well. It's not super deep, but it's enjoyable.The engine's moddable as well, I recall the official site having an eastern fantasy campaign.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Nice beginner-friendly graphical roguelike. It's from the less wackyrandom branch of roguelikes so there's less stuff you have to learn by dying constantly and not so many unfair instadeaths. This can be a good thing if you don't like RNG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t deaths, but if you enjoy Nethack-type randomness more you might find this game a bit boring.The best part of the game is the character development. There's tons of classes and races and while you start with the more usual ones like warriors and rogues, through game events you will unlock dozens more ranging from time-travellers to plague cultists with quite unique gameplay mechanics. There are tons of optional skill trees to unlock through quests so your characters will become quite varied.Minus points for the completely bland levels, monsters and itemization. There's an ADOM-type overworld map which ensures that not every area is a traditional dungeon, but the levels themselves are just plain boring with no interesting features. Then again the game does have a great auto-explore function so at least you don't have to slog through the dull mazes manually, this is a really good addition, you can fast-forward to the next encounter. Item-wise there are no consumables like the usual potions and scrolls so while it keeps the game less cluttered it also reduces the variety of events and loot a lot. The only items are gear you wear/wield so you can get bigger numbers on your character sheet, sometimes you can get artifacts/runes which grant an extra skill. Simple, but gets grindy and boring. It doesn't help that you mostly have to do the same areas again when you make a new character, they get repetitive.This game leans a bit more towards traditional RPGs because the lack of random craziness means that you usually die just when you get too cocky and proceed to a situation you can't handle and on the default difficulty you're allowed to make some mistakes. Characters seem to lead much longer lives than usually in roguelikes and a successful run takes something like 20 hours. I just wish it had more memorable and dynamic areas and enemies, but the class and skill system is still better than in most roguelikes.While there are many things that I don't like and I find the brutal unfair roguelikes more entertaining, I still think ToME is good. It's really fun to try out new character concepts and once you're getting bored with them there's something completely different you've unlocked and you start over.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Short version: This is a wonderful roguelike and well worth the price.Longer version:  Tales of Maj'Eyal is a nicely balanced turn based roguelike set in a well written world filled with lore.  The graphics are nice and simple, with many similar roguelikes using ASCII instead.  There is a nice selection of classes and races with a large amount of unlockable classes that all have interesting differences to set them apart.  For 2 examples, you could be a defensive tank with the bulwark class, or an alchemist, lobbing magic infused gems as explosives while your golem protects you.Another nice detail is the differentiation between arcane, nature and psionic abilities, including the presence of items "Infused by arcane disrupting forces", which can mess with any arcane abilities.  And what roguelike would be complete without randomly generated gear, with a nice amount of pre-generated artifacts(with written lore/descriptions) to add to the mix.  Lastly, this game also has a good selection of difficulty level, with normal, easier and nightmare unlocked by default, along with the for exploration mode, adventurer mode or roguelike mode.  As the names might suggest, the roguelike mode is permadeath, with a rare few exceptions, while adventurer mode gives you a couple lives, along with a few more as you reach the higher levels, though enemies do fully reheal if you respawn.If you're a fan of roguelikes or turn based rpgs, then this is a game well worth looking into.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Tales of Maj'Eyal is a roguelike with modern design.  Rather than being a simple dungeon crawler, it's a full-fledged RPG that plays like a roguelike - with more options for character building and more things to do.  Playing the game unlocks new races and classes to play, so permadeath isn't just a penalty, but a feature that lets you play something new and exciting.  Every race and class plays differently, so you will rarely lack for new things to do.Bottom line: beneath the seemingly simple veneer is a great game that's more than worth your time and money.

												A traditional turn-based dungeon crawler, without all of the traditional dungeon crawler inconveniences and inherent shortcomings. No consumable hoarding, no grinding, no unmanagable interfaces, tons of hotkeys available for you to bind, a mouse gesture binding feature, tons of races and classes to start and even more to unlock, the list goes on. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												What I have played of this game has been absolutely amazing, and I wish I had more time in my day to really delve into all it has to offer. This game entails the heart of what makes many love Roguelikes. All the features of a true Roguelike are in this beautiful game, and if you don't wish to go the hair-pulling route (that many of us are masochistically fond of,) you can set the lives distribution from permadeth to limited, or even infinite if you so desire. The art style is simplistic but beautiful, if not nostalgiac. Those who have been playing Roguelikes for a while or who know the genre from its roots may find a nice feel of classics such as Nethack and Iter Vehemens ad Necem (IVAN) in this game, as it keeps elements of those games, as well as the genre's originator, ROGUE itself intact, while throwing in a few modern entities that work very well.For those who like the classic roguelikes, whether it's the retro ASCII or the Tile-set based games, you'll find a lot of enjoyment in this game. A high recommendation to any pure Roguelike or Roguelite fan.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Easily one of the best roguelikes I've ever played.  You start with only the more classic character archtypes unlocked, but that's good because it gives you time to get acquainted to the game's quirks, like consumable items being replaced with cooldown timers on charms, runes and infusions.  This makes how well you do significantly less dependent on luck, and more on just how you play.Additionally, Cursed is, even in it's simplicity, the most insanely fun class I've played in any roguelike to date, and super easy to unlock.The Wiki is super useful, and it doesn't take away from the game to follow a suggested build before trying your own thing out, either.  http://te4.org/wiki/Main_Page

												This game can be found for free (legally) , but it's worth paying for.  You get a very deep game that is a good fusion of roguelike gameplay and a classic RPG- and you can change the settings to get what you desire, and you can even unlock a pure dungeon-stomp. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												Honestly, some of the most fun I've had with a roguelike, can only name a few that I'd rank higher than it. Unlike most roguelikes, there's an overworld with towns, said overworld and said towns are not randomly generated, but have fixed layouts, only the dangerous areas that would loosely define as "dungeons" are random in layout. Each option feels quite different, and usually has a somewhat unique play style, with race choice as well as class. The game doesn't exactly feel unfair until mid to late levels when the adventure starts getting into ridiculous territory.Visuals for something as lightweight as this and static sprites are quite nice, there's some 3D effects and 2D effects based on special abilities being used, the sprites are large and detailed enough to know what you're facing before you mouse over it.Controls are fairly simple, opting for an action bar where you can slot all your different items/abilities, which may deter some of the hardcore players of roguelikes. There's also mouse support, and right clicking on your character or other things allows one to play mostly with the mouse if one prefers.Sound is present, there's music for every area, sounds for different attacks and special abilities, nothing to really write home about, but it's not bad.Game mechanics are fairly solid and scale up to the point of more or less halfling going toe to toe with kaiju god-slaying robot of death, though quite a few of the mechanics are not 100% intuitive, difficulty is pretty variable with lots of options. Achievements are a colossal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥though, as a result, as getting an achievement in one difficulty setting doesn't unlock it for any others, and a lot of the achievements have 12 variations or so based on difficulty settings. Will say that some randomly generated enemies can be impossible to kill, I had an issue with a named bone giant who was impossible to kill at the level cap with ridiculously strong abilities as a summoner.The game also has a plot and rewards you for being a nice person or a total jerk as well. It's not super deep, but it's enjoyable.The engine's moddable as well, I recall the official site having an eastern fantasy campaign.

TOME has decent looking (for roguelike standards) art, countless build possibilities (thanks to its in-depth character customization), and fun combat that actually involves the usage of skills as opposed to just bumping into enemies the entire time.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												I don't like traditional roguelikes. Dungeons of Dredmor was too much too fast, and nethack is waaaay too much. ToME is the first traditional roguelike I've actually enjoyed! Its tutorial is decent and you start off slow. There's far fewer variables than nethack while still keeping everything complex and interesting. The graphics are alright for its genre.If you want to try the game, get it from their website for free. It's only missing a few gameplay features that I don't even use, like easy mode and a Double Shield class. Shame that you won't get female beards though.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												I've played a lot of roguelikes before. Most of them feel like one long dungeon run. Some of them have a sort of level select (crypt of the necrodancer) or progress through different levels (rogues legacy/binding of isaac).But none of them had the feeling like you were an adventurer, going on YOUR OWN adventure. They kind of drop you in a dungeon and say "have fun, here's your dungeon".But in TOME (tales of maj'eyal) you got an overworld map. You can go to really difficult areas or fight random adventurers who just roam around. There's towns you can visit and tons of shops.It's very immersive, especially for a roguelike. It makes me want to play some pen and paper D&D again.And there's a ton of skills and items you can get. And lots of random events. Many random bosses / minibosses who will destroy you. There's just a TON of content. It's not difficult to get into, although discerning what loot is useful or not is definitely beyond casual.You can chat with other players, which even in a single player game can add a lot. You can see when people die, which even if you aren't talking to them, is interesting to watch.And my personal favorite feature is that you can have multiple lives. It's not a great feature in the spirit of roguelikes, but in the spirit of gaming it's fantastic. This is usually an instant "omg this game sucks and isn't a roguelike". But I love everything about these type of RPGs, EXCEPT for the permadeath.For some reason, finding a mix of roguelike aspects in a non-roguelike RPG is impossible. That is, things like traps, random events, deep character customizations, random/persistent effects, and just general "I have no idea what this will do, but I'll try it". The ONLY game that ever came close to that which I know of is Din's Curse. Although TOME has the feature as a gamemode, so that's fantastic.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												I wish I'd heard about this game sooner!It's SO FUN. I've already played it for 20 hours and I'm not even close to being done with it! I just want to keep playing all the time. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys roguelikes, and I think most people that enjoy RPGs could enjoy this as well. Don't be fooled by its price, or relatively low amount of players compared to games like FTL or TBOI (which I also love!): This game is rich to no end, intriguing, fun, difficult, interesting, enjoyable. You get much more content for your money than any other game I've seen before. With a huge variety of unique classes and races you can form your own playstyle and stick to it; Or otherwise you can explore, discovering little bits and pieces of the huge world though the races' personal stories and some class unique events.You can get it for free on their website if you don't want to buy it. I got it on sale for 1.80$ and I don't regret it one bit. It's worth so much more than the full price, you're basically getting charged pocket money for what it is. It almost feels like a scam.I cannot stress the amount of content there is in this game and how excited I am to explore it all. It's simply amazing!

												Amazing roguelike game, challenging but not unfair and easier to get into than many other roguelikes. If you're unfamiliar with then genre, think  turn based Diablo. There is a huge selection of classes to choose from, and you can play the same class multiple ways since you have a limited amout of skill points. The game's tileset looks great, but there is an ASCII mode too if you prefer that. The music is well done, and so are the sound effects.The game is available free on the developers website if you'd like to try it out, but you wont have access to a lot of features that come with the paid version, mostly an item stash and Steam Workshop mods. Definately worth picking up.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Nice beginner-friendly graphical roguelike. It's from the less wackyrandom branch of roguelikes so there's less stuff you have to learn by dying constantly and not so many unfair instadeaths. This can be a good thing if you don't like RNG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t deaths, but if you enjoy Nethack-type randomness more you might find this game a bit boring.The best part of the game is the character development. There's tons of classes and races and while you start with the more usual ones like warriors and rogues, through game events you will unlock dozens more ranging from time-travellers to plague cultists with quite unique gameplay mechanics. There are tons of optional skill trees to unlock through quests so your characters will become quite varied.Minus points for the completely bland levels, monsters and itemization. There's an ADOM-type overworld map which ensures that not every area is a traditional dungeon, but the levels themselves are just plain boring with no interesting features. Then again the game does have a great auto-explore function so at least you don't have to slog through the dull mazes manually, this is a really good addition, you can fast-forward to the next encounter. Item-wise there are no consumables like the usual potions and scrolls so while it keeps the game less cluttered it also reduces the variety of events and loot a lot. The only items are gear you wear/wield so you can get bigger numbers on your character sheet, sometimes you can get artifacts/runes which grant an extra skill. Simple, but gets grindy and boring. It doesn't help that you mostly have to do the same areas again when you make a new character, they get repetitive.This game leans a bit more towards traditional RPGs because the lack of random craziness means that you usually die just when you get too cocky and proceed to a situation you can't handle and on the default difficulty you're allowed to make some mistakes. Characters seem to lead much longer lives than usually in roguelikes and a successful run takes something like 20 hours. I just wish it had more memorable and dynamic areas and enemies, but the class and skill system is still better than in most roguelikes.While there are many things that I don't like and I find the brutal unfair roguelikes more entertaining, I still think ToME is good. It's really fun to try out new character concepts and once you're getting bored with them there's something completely different you've unlocked and you start over.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Don't be fooled by the simple, tile-based graphics. This is easily the most polished roguelike I've played. It demands a lot of thought, and rewards you with deep and engaging gameplay with important choices to make on multiple levels. As you progress through the story and unlock more races, classes, and skills, the number of possible play styles available multiplies. It takes a lot of time to even begin to master, but is compartmentalized in a way that allows you to play in short doses if your life is generally busy.One warning: don't get this game if you're a compulsive completionist. There are close to 1400 achievements; it's simply impossible to do more than a relative handful of them unless you're one of those lucky YouTube entertainers who plays games for a living.

												Ahhh TOME what a beautiful game! I love it and so should you. It's the best traditional roguelike out there. Yes you heard me right: THE BEST. I played tons of roguelikes, and by that I mean over 50 or so ; D. And still, there is no game that can live up to this gem. It has all you want: #Deep and interesting lore#Tons of races and classes# Vast and complex skill trees that allow you to personalize your gameplay#Tons of items#It’s insanely long (for a roguelike)#Loads of caves, ruins, forests, other dimensions, and towns to explore#It's straight up funAnd all that greatness comes packaged in one game. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												There's really only 1 thing that bothers me about this game - unlocking an achievement on a higher difficulty setting doesn't do the same for a lower difficulty. Given that I'll never play on anything but roguelike, that leaves me with a bunch of achievements I'll never get.Other than that, this is a great roguelike. It is class based so there are some choice moments when you really wish you could use that awesome item you found, but that's true of most of the genre. Most of what I've seen has been that good choices and skill synergy trumps RNG drops.Starting out, your choices are pretty limited. You need to fulfill certain requirements to unlock additional races and classes. Thankfully, these conditions aren't hard to fulfill and will (mostly) naturally happen as you progress through the game. I was kind of annoyed by that, but it did give me a chance to play around with some of the basic skill trees and get a feel for the combat styles in this game.If you do pick this up, I'd recommend taking a look at some of the add-ons like the advanced item compare, better escorts and improved sorting. I played my first 70 or so hours without them, but they do improve QoL.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												This a (mostly) well made RPG that is very fun to play8/10Pros:-Good storyline-Lots of interesting lore and history to be discovered-Reminds me of good classic RPGs (such as rogue, obviously, and D&D)-Not easy or annoyingly difficult-Lots of classes and races to unlock-Lots of interesting gear to find-Balanced leveling-up and skill unlock system-Very fun to playCons:-There are large walls of text that give lore, history, and important plot information-You might not get the whole "feel" of the game if you don't read these walls of text-Some of the side-quests are hard, and it can be frustrating if you fail them-There is no rewinding to fix failed side-quests, because of the auto-save and you can only have one save for each run at a time (in other words, if you fail a side-quest you're screwed)-There's a HUGE amount of key bindings to memorize-Movement is with arrow keys by default and it is extremely annoying to rebind them to wsad-It seems like the person who wrote the text in the game doesn't speek English as a first language because some of it is awkwardly writen and/or has basic grammer errors. (Although this isn't often enough to lower my enjoyment of the game)

												The person w/the 2,300 hours convinced me to buy this. Is that a glitch? Holy smokes!Back in like 1990 I had a friend who's father had a gaming room w/his computer setup. He was like a god amongst us kids because the games on the computer were so unreal compared to Nintendo.Anyway...he would play something that looked like ToME, and have maps/posters up all over his walls. I believe they were OLD D&D turn based games for DOS. This game took me right back to being there, standing in awe, watching his father play. This game transported me back to that time.Thanks for that. Now I have to go tell my wife why I haven't really done anything around here lately.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												This rougelike keeps destroying me, yet I keep coming back for more. It might take an hour or so of playing to really understand what's going on and how the game works, but once you figure it out the game really opens up.Pros:- Many races and classes to choose from, allows for quite a few styles of play- Combat greatly rewards the use of tactics- Turn-based, so you can take as long as you need to to strategizeCons:- Campaign mode is quite long, can easily play a character for 6 hours then have them die, which is heart-breaking- Loot doesn't seem to matter much for magic-based characters. Also not much incentive to buy anything as a mage either.- Although dungeons have random layouts, the campaign mode is pretty much the same every time. This can make the beginning of the game tedious once you've done it several times and it doesn't really changeNeutral:- Graphics. I personally like the graphics in the game, but some might find them datedAll in all I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys difficult, turn-based rpg's. If for some reason you hate grinding or repetition, you ay have problems with this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Even though I have tried to post other game reviews, they never are posted for some reason or another. So with that in mind, this is my "first" review. My experience within this game is limited (37.9 hrs at time of post), but my time with this game may be much more when looked at in the future. Now lets get to the meat of the review, the pros and cons.Pros:+Great, meticulous tactical gameplay+An intricate skill tree system (Which can be expanded through various events)+Unforgiving (given that it is a rougelike game)+Dedicated support from DarkGod, the sole developer (He has been working on this game for over 17 years!)+Good support for mods and addons+Enticing lore! The world feels very alive and the stories are very well thought out.+Fun and deep character creation, especially as you unlock classes and races+Interesting classes (I bet your other RPGs don't have Oozemancers or Temproal Wardens!)+A good community+Very challenging and it will test your abilities+The game can be downloaded for free on its website. You won't have access to some small features but you can unlock those by donating money to DarkGod. Otherwise, you can just buy through Steam and get those goodies right off the bat, like I did. +An exploration mode with infinate lives. You can accustom yourself to the game and tinker with various builds and whatnot (This is a special perk for those who donate should you download it from its website) +Alternative modes to play should you get bored of the main story lines (Infinite Dungeon and Arena) Cons:-Graphics are quite dated but this is largely a non-issue. The developer started working on this game in the late 1990s so the engine that the game runs on is very old. Could potentially deter gamers who have only really experienced more recent games like Skyrim, Diablo 3, etc. But you know, their loss.-Can be rage inducing. The amount of times you die is ridiculous and due to the RNG within the game, you can get very unlucky and run into a monster or mob that erases your pixelated♥♥♥♥♥ But hey, you knew what you signed up for ;)-Bugs, crashing, etc. Though these are rare, there have been hiccups which might kill you or just cause you to crash. (I know of one with a passive which allows you to speed up immensely for a short time after killing an enemy and moving with it may cause your game to crash. It has happened to me many times but it was just an annoyance since I set back to my previous save point) It's minor, but something to keep in mind since you can be punished brutally if you make a mistake.Conclusion:This is just a great game and one that recieves so much love. Being someone who is relatively new to the "Rougelike" genre of games, this game has got me hooked! Outside of the few minor annoyances, this is a full, flushed out game. This thing has recieved more time and dedication than most marriages do in the U.S. (lol) There is so much story and content to this game, most of which I have yet to experience for myself. This game is frustrating in the best of ways. It drives you to go further, try new classes, races, etc. DarkGod (from what I have seen and heard) is very active and continues to work on content for this game. One example is the new expansion he released in February, "Embers of Rage" and he has hinted at more expansions that he is or will be working on in the future. He also will create special events in the game and play with those currently playing. I wholeheartedly reccomend this game to those who enjoy a good RPG or rougelike game. It is one in a long string of games that I have enjoyed so much that I binged on it. While this game was released on Steam in 2012 and is a bit dated, I will support this diamond in the rough and I hope you do too!

												When I first looked at it - let's just say I was not impressed.It looked like a browser MMO knock-off: brigtish colours, long-donkey bar (that'd not be customisable I bet and ofcourse no shortcuts etc.). Prolly got like 3 cookie-cutter races/classes combo, gender locked on top of that.Boy, was I in for a surprise.Tales are a beautiful, complex and deep game with a plenty of room to make your build, your characted - the way you want it. Wanna have a hulking ghoulish brute ogre? Here you go. A hulking ogre brute ghoul? You know were I'm getting.The plot itself is pretty linear, but offers some motivation and intertainment.Also It is obvious (for me, at least) that the devs are big, big, BIG fans of pnp boardgames - and the game itself, being a generalised homage of some of them, racking some xtra points from your truly.

												I got this game thinking it mitght be something good, but i wasn't too impressed with the videos in the store page (note: I'm not one to judge "bad" or "outdated" graphsics, I actually enjoy ToME (Tales of Maj'Eyal) graphics).After I installed it and played the tutorial i was a little overwhelmed with the possibilities and startet an elven alchemist run. Because I had no clue of all the graphical cues and I didnt know that i was getting rekt untill it was too late I died on the very first floor.  After that I startet a human Archer and got out of the first area killing the boss and I was proud of my achievements.Ater only a few runs I was hooked and couldn't stop playing the game for 30 hours in 5 days. I have never ever experienced something like it and had to take a break from the game since I was very frustrated for beeing bad :PI encourage everyone that loves rouge-like RPGs to get this game, you can play for many many hours.Pros:Great level and enemy variety and no run is the sameMany different races and classes with many different skills for a nigh unlimited replayabilityYou can unlock many classes, races and skills and there are many achivements to get (pretty much impossible to get all)Many different resources like mana, vim, psi...You can disable permadeath and choose either unlimited deaths or limited deaths insteadloads of loreThe "only one more turn" problem some games have. I lost lots of sleep because it suddenly was 4AMCons:You can get ♥♥♥♥ed by RNGSome classes are really bad and others are god-worthyIt will take you some time to get used to the UI and graphics, but once you got it its great.You will die. alot. sometimes very early on and othertimes to an incredibly powerful foe who randomly spawned there only to ♥♥♥♥ you over even though you had your best run so far. I love that but might be a big nogo for some people.Sometimes it laggs a bitThe "only one more turn" problem some games have. I lost lots of sleep because it suddenly was 4AM(this is both good and bad)There are probably many more things i didn't mention because i forgot. and I lost gametime on steam for some odd reason, i have like 20 hours more in the game than whats displayed.TL:DRGreat game for a great price with great replayability.

Posted: September 3, 2015
												Holy crap it has live events!The game is tileset turn base with mouse support. Its looks old but has a lot of modern elements added on. If you like tatical turn base cRPGs and don't mind tilesets then this is seriously a great game. SO MUCH CUSTOMIZATION! So many choices and so many ways you will die... but fear not as there are a few game modes ranging from infinite lives to true roguelike. Easy to play but its got a really robust mechanic system. Also has modding support. Tons of gear, tons of weapons, tons of monsters, tons of areas, tons of lore, and a stupidly high number of race/classes (of which u get to choose how they level and play via skills and perks and the RNG gear)Oh ya and no grinding. Once u clear a floor or whole dungeon its cleared for good. I think new hostiles can spawn on the overworld map though like hostile patrols, though not 100% sure.I should mention the game is 100% free (aside from the DLC) at te4.org though its made and maintsianed by 1 dude so worth it to buy it if you like it. And u can connect online to play but you won't see anyone as you are more or less just uploading your data and sometimes u might be playing and recieve a special world event because u were lucky to be logged in when it started :)4/5 is my personal rating for the game. Its great verging on fantatsic! And I would recomend this to more mature older gamers like myself. People that play D&D or really old games.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4
												This is mostly an old-fashioned turn-based roguelike (by opposition to rogue-lites like Spelunky and Binding of Isaac, which are usually real-time), though it lacks the item identification and the potion and scroll consumables we've come to love from its ancestor Angband, or better titles like NetHack and Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup. It also really likes cooldown-based abilities, so at times you'll feel like you're doing MMO combat.I found the game too easy initially on Normal, starting the game as a Cornac Berserker regular enemies were no challenge at all, only bosses took some work to kill. The game also drops you in a forest which is quite boring to explore, and the graphics don't make very clear which tiles are traversable and which are not. I recommend using the auto-explore function ('Z' key, rebindable) in levels where you're mostly meeting trash mobs.With time the game ups the challenge (and you can run into very dangerous areas if you're not careful, the game gives you a message which alludes to the difficulty when changing zones), and with level-ups you start discovering the deep RPG and item system. No complaints here, developing and equipping your character is very interesting, even though the game drowns you a in a sea of magic items with prefixes and suffixes, like Diablo and its ilk. (And unlike diablo, it has a lot of very small modifications to 10+ damage types. Yawning when you find yet another super-rare/legendary is never a good sign.) You unlock new characters and features through quests in the game, which I found cool.Combat is quite compelling whenever there's a sense of danger. As in most roguelikes, not getting surrounded and paying attention to everything before making a move is key. Between equipment, infusions/runes and skills, you have a lot of abilities with cooldowns, so most turns will be spent picking the right one or positioning yourself to use one rather than simply running into an enemy to auto-attack. What I was most impressed with is when facing boss-type characters, they use pretty much the same ability system as you, and they sometimes have a lot of skills. While it makes identifying a dangerous enemy at a glance pretty hard, it does make for rather epic fights as they cast spells, heal and trigger cooldown abilities just like you. Trust me, the first time you meet an enemy with knockback and spells is really scary when playing a melee character.The interface, however, is REALLY AWFUL (despite ridiculous frontpage claims of "modern graphical and customisable interface, intuitive mouse control"), especially the inventory. It's not really comfortable to use with the mouse: instead of displaying a tooltip for what you're hovering your cursor over, it insists on always having some object selected, obscuring your view with the information display. Movement with the mouse is also not very intuitive, as your character will move to where you point... until it finds something "interesting" or an enemy, and then you have to revert to moving a square at a time if you want any semblance of control. It would actually seem like a good idea to learn the game solely with the keyboard at first, maybe even play another, keyboard only roguelike before this one. Only then will the mouse control layer make full sense. There's also a problem of information overload when looking at map tiles (and other stuff): do I really need to know that I need a "special breathing method" to traverse walls everytime I'm looking at one? The game cruelly needs to display only crucial information at a glance, and then offer to say, press shift to show detailed info like now in the tooltip (see Civilization IV and V and its most complex mods for good examples).The game has a fixed overworld, story elements and quite a bit of lore, which set it apart from NetHack and Crawl which only offer a giant dungeon. I found this refreshing, but I it comes with suggested level indications for dungeons and minimum levels to use some items, very jarring and immersion-breaking compared to the natural increase in difficulty as you go down in levels in other titles. It's gonna have a massive impact on replayability, too, the world map feels pretty small. There are towns and shops to return to and sell your loot: I think I slightly prefer the approach of Crawl where you can't sell stuff or transfer it to other characters, so you just dump stuff you don't need without hesitation. But if you like sorting through tons of loot Diablo or Borderlands-style, you'll be happy with this game.There's no downside to resting ('R' key) in this game. In fact I recommend resting as soon as you finish beating a group of enemies, to recharge your health and stamina and bring all your abilities off cooldown. (Annoyingly, some charge bars like "equilibrium" which is need for some powers are ignore by the rest function, leading you to spam the skip turn button or use a mod if you want to get back into an optimal state.) Having to spam rest like this doesn't feel too great, it feels like the game had a hunger mechanic like other roguelikes to urge you on and prevent abusing rest, but dropped it along the way leaving Rest feeling orphaned.There are a few other weird leftovers in the game, like a "Scrying Orb" which auto-identifies objects... and is completely pointless since objects always auto-identify in this game. Somehow the author hacked that in with a magical item at some point and left it as-is. Also, most annoyingly the game drowns you in loot but unlike, say, Crawl, anything you leave on the floor will disappear after a while. EXCEPT in "vaults", small enclosed areas with treasure guarded by monsters. Good luck identifying what was a vault when coming back to an area you've cleared, though, there are no indications except the room shape. This is an annoying non-feature you'll feel compelled to use, if only to stash stuff until you find the player home (which is also the in-game location of your te4.org, microtransaction-fueled online item Vault), or to make sets of element-resistant armor for various situations.Overall I quite like the game, but it has a lot of room for improvements in the UI and graphics clarity department. Some of the gameplay choices made that set it apart from other roguelikes give a different, but not necessarily better experience. And as mentioned there are small but nasty oversights in the game design, which ends up feeling like a work in progress based on other roguelikes rather than its own thought-out entity. The community also seems to be blind to most of these flaws, and over-protective of any choice the author makes.Try it out to experience the sheer amount of content a true roguelike can offer, but do expect a flawed gem. It might be the best game in the Angband family of roguelikes, having gotten rid of annoying stuff like non-persistent levels while still offering mechanics pretty unique to the family like multiplying creatures.You can go to my Steam profile for more info on classical Roguelikes and suggestion of both free and paid ones.

												I'm not usually a fan of roguelikes, but ToME has won my heart. ToME is superbly written: the storyline, dialogs, lore are all fully fleshed out, and even item descriptions are interesting.ToME's combat is fun: every class is unique and interesting, and each class completely changes the way you play the game. But most important of all, the game is well-balanced. Every class can finish the game, and even if you die you don't feel like it was an impossible situation. Oh, did I mention you are given additional lives at specific levels so you can resurrect yourself if you reeeeeeeaaaallly want? I wish more roguelikes had this option, haha.ToME is a fantastic roguelike and I would recommend it to any fan of the genre.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												This game is fantastic if you are into roguelikes and/or old school RPGs. I'm somewhat OCD about saving all consumables in games like this, to the point that I never end up using them, so I LOVE the fact that they don't exist in ToME! Instead you get limited scroll/potion slots (infusions) that function the same, but work of a cooldown and therefore don't make me feel guilty at all for using them. Many parts of the game have reveal similar attention to removing non-fun parts of the genre without resorting to over-simplifying it (or indeed simplifying at all, this is still quite a complex game!), such as the fact that when you begin you still have the similar loot/encumbrance/return-to-town-to-sell cycle, but before too long you get an account-wide unlockable item to instantly sell anything that you pick up.

Posted: December 18, 2013
												YES!  ToME is finally on steam!  If you have never played this game, you can download a copy to try at te4.org.  If you enjoy tactical RPGs and rogue-likes, forget trying it, just go buy it, now.  I have been playing this game since about halfway through its beta, and its truly an amazing game.  Punishingly hard if you are careless, but rewards those who learn to really use the abilities of their character.  And oh, the abilities.  Pick one of the 24 (!) classes (fewer at first--you have to unlock the advanced classes through gameplay; this is a good thing, as you would get slaughtered playing these classes as a new player!) and pick one of the 9 races (again, some require unlocks).  These combine to determine which ability groups you get to put points into.  And points can be scarce--pretty much all character classes can be played 2 or 3 different ways, and some can be done 4 or more different ways, depending upon how you spread your points around.  Add in a mostly-fixed overland map with mostly-procedurally generated dungeons and some tough boss and miniboss fights and an amazingly varied loot system...and you've got a game with frightening levels of replayability.  And for good measure, add a developer (All hail DarkGod!) who listens to feedback, talks with his players on the forums, and seems to spend more time than is physically posible working on the game.  (Maybe he is a Chronomancer?)  What are you waiting for?

Posted: December 31, 2013
												Let me get some things out of the way first. No, this isn't a great looking game. If you're looking for smooth animation, amazing visuals, flashy effects, etc., you won't find them here. The music isn't great (I play with it muted and one of the many video game and movie soundtracks I have on itunes playing in the background), and sometimes the ambience is a little annoying (whoever owns the dog that barks nonstop in every city needs to put a muzzle on it or something). Now, for the good things. The gameplay is hard as nails, unforgiving, confusing at times, and all around frustratingly hard, as any good roguelike should be. You have to option to play with more lives, even infinite lives, but I always play on the "roguelike" mode, where you only have one life, unless you find more. Knowing what is happening around you at all times is a must in this game, as losing focus of even one enemy can mean death, as I learned the hard way in my most recent death (opened a door, orc necromancer on the other side, managed to escape at first, but on my way back to see if I could get around him, was flanked by his summoned army of skeletons and ghouls). This is a true roguelike, with everything happening in turns as you wander through forests and dungeons, killing everything in your path, picking up loot, buying weapons and armour, and, when you make a mistake, dying with no continues or reloads (at least on roguelike mode). All in all, a really fun game full of challenges and endless replayability. 7.5 / 10

Posted: April 20, 2014
												ToME combines the depth of the classical RPG, the friendly user interface of the modern cRPGs like Diablo, and the challenge and replayability of a good roguelike game. Unncessary complexities that might otherwise make a turn-based dungeon crawler tedious are streamlined using functionalities like auto-explore, auto-cast, and auto-sell. At the same time, the game retains all the complexities related character customization and strategy. There are 25 classes, and nearly all of them play very differently from the others. Adding to the strategic depth is the amount of effects the environment can have on a character, from vision blocked by fog to getting crushed by collasping walls to suffocated in water. The dungeon design makes great use of these elements. There is always something new to look forward to when you start a new game, which is a great news, because the game is challenging enough that it's only a matter of time before your first character runs out of lives.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												The first thought you'll have if you aren't familiar with the sub-genre of roguelikes after looking at screenshots/videos is that this game is primitive. What I can say after almost 30 hours put in to the game is that looks can be deceiving.Hidden behind the smoke of a 2D tileset is a shockingly rich, deep, & complex RPG which will constantly test your skills in character development and strategic combat. Like many of its irk this is game which with almost every failure you walk away with new found knowledge which will allow you to (potentially) proceed further upon your next playthrough.I would personally recommend the roguelike difficulty for fans of the sub-genre as this is how i initially delved into and enjoyed the game but if permadeath leaves you squeamish there are alernative game modes which will allow you to learn the game without losing a character after a single death. I expect to spend many more hours learning and enjoying this gem.

												TL;DR fantastic ♥♥♥♥ing game by a fantastic ♥♥♥♥ing creator that is worth every ♥♥♥♥ing penny 9/10So I know my time played doesn't reflect this, but back way before the oozemancer came out in this game, there was a period where I didn't have any real internet connectivity for two years, which made playing any type of game impossible and downloading anything the same.
